title: 110_s1672
content: The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes the Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Education Assistance Program under Chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes a scholarship program to provide financial assistance for individuals studying visual impairment or orientation and mobility. The purpose is to increase the supply of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists for the Department and the Nation. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes a scholarship program to increase the supply of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists for the Department and the Nation. The Secretary will publicize the program to educational institutions, with a focus on Hispanic students and Historically Black Colleges and Universities. To apply, individuals must submit an application and agreement for obligated service in return for educational assistance. Application forms will include a summary of rights and liabilities for approved individuals. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes a scholarship program for blind rehabilitation specialists. Upon approval by the Secretary, individuals are notified in writing of their acceptance. The amount of financial assistance provided covers tuition and fees necessary for the program of study. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 provides financial assistance for blind rehabilitation specialists, with a maximum annual amount of $15,000 for full-time students and $45,000 overall. Assistance can supplement other educational aid, and the program has a maximum duration set by the Secretary. The Secretary may provide financial assistance to an individual for up to six years under the VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007. An agreement between the Secretary and a participant in the scholarship program must be in writing and include the participant's agreement to accept financial assistance, maintain enrollment, academic standing, and serve as a full-time employee in the Department after completing the program. The Secretary may provide financial assistance to an individual for up to six years under the VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007. An agreement must be in writing and include the participant's agreement to accept financial assistance, maintain enrollment, academic standing, and serve as a full-time employee in the Department for three years within the first six years after completing the program. Repayment is required if the individual fails to satisfy the agreement, with the Secretary determining the amount and circumstances for repayment. The Secretary can waive or suspend obligations for service or payment under the VA Vision Scholars Act if noncompliance is beyond the individual's control or in the best interest of the United States. Any repayment obligation is considered a debt to the United States, not discharged by bankruptcy within five years of agreement termination. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must implement chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code, within six months of the enactment of this Act.
